constructs.name: weekend_work
constructs.description: Amount of work done on Saturday and Sunday, including checking emails, completing tasks, or attending meetings

constructs.name: weekday_task_completion
constructs.description: Proportion of planned work tasks completed during regular weekday work hours (Monday-Friday)

constructs.name: work_urgency_perception
constructs.description: Subjective sense of deadline pressure and how urgent current work demands feel

constructs.name: boundary_enforcement
constructs.description: Active behaviors to maintain work-life separation: saying no, not checking email, turning off notifications

constructs.name: weekday_productivity
constructs.description: Efficiency and effectiveness of work output during weekday work hours

constructs.name: energy_level
constructs.description: Physical and mental energy available for work and activities throughout the day

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Quality and restorative nature of sleep, including duration and depth

constructs.name: work_stress
constructs.description: Anxiety, worry, and mental burden related to work demands and performance

constructs.name: exercise_engagement
constructs.description: Physical activity and exercise participation during the day

constructs.name: available_focus_time
constructs.description: Hours available for uninterrupted deep work, free from meetings and interruptions

constructs.name: meeting_load
constructs.description: Time spent in scheduled meetings, calls, and synchronous work interactions

constructs.name: procrastination_behavior
constructs.description: Avoidance of work tasks, delaying important work in favor of less demanding activities

constructs.name: after_hours_connectivity
constructs.description: Checking work communications (email, Slack, etc.) outside normal work hours in evenings

constructs.name: workload_volume
constructs.description: Total amount of work tasks and responsibilities assigned or taken on

constructs.name: planning_quality
constructs.description: Effectiveness of weekly and daily planning, including realistic time estimates and prioritization

constructs.name: delegation_behavior
constructs.description: Active distribution of tasks to others and seeking help when overwhelmed

constructs.name: job_demands_profile
constructs.description: Inherent demands of the job type and industry, including baseline expectations for availability

constructs.name: organizational_culture
constructs.description: Company and team norms around work hours, responsiveness, and weekend work expectations

constructs.name: perfectionism_tendency
constructs.description: Trait-level perfectionism and need for high standards that can drive overwork

constructs.name: career_stage
constructs.description: Career level and seniority affecting autonomy, delegation ability, and expectations

constructs.name: financial_pressure
constructs.description: Level of financial obligations and concerns that may drive job insecurity and overwork

edges.description: Incomplete weekday work directly spills over into weekend work to catch up
High perceived urgency drives working weekends to meet pressing deadlines
Active boundary-setting directly reduces weekend work by creating protective barriers
Habit of checking work communications leads to getting pulled into weekend work
Work anxiety drives compulsive checking and working to reduce worry
Company norms around availability directly shape weekend work expectations
Higher daily productivity enables completing more tasks within the work week
Higher workload makes it harder to complete all tasks during weekdays
Procrastination during the week reduces task completion, creating spillover
Better planning with realistic estimates improves weekday completion rates
Higher energy enables sustained focus and efficient work output
More uninterrupted time allows for deep work and higher productivity
High stress impairs cognitive function and reduces work effectiveness
Good sleep restores physical and mental energy for the next day
Regular exercise increases overall energy levels and vitality
Physical activity improves sleep quality and duration
Work-related anxiety and rumination impair sleep quality
Checking work communications at night disrupts wind-down and sleep onset
More meetings directly reduce time available for focused work
Anxiety about difficult tasks leads to avoidance and procrastination
Low energy reduces motivation and increases task avoidance
Higher workload creates more perceived deadline pressure
Company urgency culture shapes individual perception of deadline pressure
Active delegation reduces personal workload burden
Job type determines baseline workload expectations
Job type determines how meeting-intensive the role is
More senior roles have greater ability and expectation to delegate
Career stage affects scope of responsibilities and workload
Perfectionism creates chronic worry about work quality and performance
Perfectionism undermines ability to set boundaries and accept good enough
Financial concerns create job insecurity and performance anxiety
High stress undermines confidence to enforce work-life boundaries
Supportive culture makes boundary-setting easier; always-on culture undermines it
Working weekends disrupts recovery time and sleep patterns
Working weekends increases burnout and chronic work-related stress
Company norms shape expectations around checking messages after hours
Anxiety drives compulsive checking of work communications
Higher workload creates more pressure and work-related anxiety
Good planning with clear priorities improves daily work efficiency
Higher energy makes it easier to engage in exercise
Poor sleep increases stress reactivity and reduces emotional regulation
Procrastinating on tasks creates accumulating stress about incomplete work
High stress impairs executive function needed for effective planning
